IN THE COURT OF THE SESSIONS JUDGE,
THIRUVANANTHAPURAM
PRESENT : SMT. NAZEERA.S, SESSIONS JODGE
On Monday, 3 day of March 2025/12" day of Phalguna, 1946.
Criminal M.C.No. 648/2025
Crime No 238/2025 of Kattakada Police Station
Petitioner/Accused No. 1 :-

Rojin John J aged 29 years S/o. John C

residing at Rojin Bhavan, Kazhachikkadu

Chandramangalam, Thiruvananthapuram

By Advocate:- Ananda Subramaniam
Counter Petitioners :-

1. State of Kerala
2. The Station House Officer
Kattakada Police Station Thiruvananthapuram
By Public Prosecutor Dr. T. Geenakumari

This Criminal M.C. is coming on for hearing on 01.03.2025 and the court

on 03.03.2025 passed the following
ORDER

This is the 2" application filed under Section 482 of the Bharatiya
Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, seeking pre-arrest bail.

2. The petitioner is alleged to have committed the offences punishable
under Sections 126(2), 296(b), 115(2), 118(1), 110, 351(3) and 324(4) of the
Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, and Crime No. 238/2025 of Kattakada Police Station
is registered against the petitioner arraying him as the 1* accused.

3. The prosecution allegation in brief is as follows:- Due to enmity
towards the defacto complainant, on 08.02.2025 at about 7 p.m., while the

2

defacto complainant was going home along with his wife and his two children,
in a scooter, and when they reached in the road in front of the house of the
accused situated at Kazhinjikkadu, the 1* accused wrongfully restrained the
defacto complainant, abused him and slapped him on his left cheek, and when
the defacto complainant questioned the said acts, the 1* accused, by using a
reaper, beat on his back, and when the wife of the defacto complainant
intervened, the 1* accused beat her on her back with his right hand. Then, the
2™4 accused, who reached there at that time, using a reaper, beat on the head of
the defacto complainant, and when prevented, it hit on his head and right hand,
causing injuries. When the defacto complainant fell down, the 2™ accused
threatened him, abused him and kicked him on his chest, and the 1* accused, by
using the reaper, damaged the bike, causing a total loss to the tune of
Rs.15,000/- to the defacto complainant.

4. Notice in this bail application is issued to the Public Prosecutor.
The Investigating Officer filed report opposing the anticipatory bail application.

5. The earlier pre-arrest bail application filed by the petitioner was
dismissed by this Court as per Order dated 19.02.2025 in Criminal M.C.No.
482/2025.

6. Heard. Perused the records.

7. The only point to be considered is, whether an order of anticipatory
bail can be granted to the petitioner/ 1* accused.

3

8. The Point:- The petitioner/ 1“ accused along with the 2™
accused is alleged to have restrained the defacto complainant and his family,
while they were going to their house in a scooter, abused the defacto
complainant, and by using reapers, attacked him and damaged his scooter. The
petitioner/1* accused assaulted the wife of the defacto complainant also. The
motive as alleged is the misunderstanding of the accused persons that the
defacto complainant informed the police that they assaulted the grandmother of
the petitioner/1* accused.

9. According to the petitioner, he and his father are absolutely
innocent of the allegations levelled against them and they have not committed
any offences as alleged. It is submitted that, on the alleged date of incident, at
about 6 p.m., the defacto complainant trespassed into the house of the
petitioner, uttered abusive words, and attacked him, and thereafter, the defacto
complainant preferred a false complaint against the petitioner. The petitioner
submits that, there is delay in lodging the First Information Report.

10. There is serious allegation as against the petitioner. Allegedly, the
petitioner/ 1 accused along with the 2™ accused had abused and attacked the
defacto complainant, using reapers, and assaulted his wife. In the body note
with the First Information Statement, it is noted that, a healed wound is seen on
the head of the defacto complainant and abrasion is on the right side of his
chest. So, the prosecution has made out a prima facie case against the
petitioner/ 1 accused and regarding the involvement of the petitioner in the

4

alleged offence. It is stated in the report that the seat cover and cushion cover
of the motorcycle, and a reaper used for the commission of the offence, were
recovered and the wound certificate is obtained. It is seen from the report that
the loss sustained due to damaging of the motorcycle is primarily assessed as
Rs.15,000/-. The investigation is progressing. It is reported that the 1*
petitioner is involved in one another crime. Considering the facts stated in the
report to the effect that the petitioner is involved in the offence, it appears that
exceptional jurisdiction to grant a pre-arrest bail cannot be exercised in this
case.

11. In Jai Prakash Singh v. State of Bihar and Another (2012 (4)
SCC 379), the Hon’ble Apex court has held that, an order of pre-arrest bail
being an extra ordinary privilege, should be granted only in exceptional cases. It
is settled in law that arrest should be the last option and it should be restricted to
cases where arrest is imperative in the facts and circumstances of a case and
consistent view is that the grant of anticipatory bail shall be restricted to
exceptional circumstances. So it is clear that the power to grant anticipatory bail
under section 482 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita. is an exceptional
power and should be exercised only in exceptional cases and not as a matter of
course. Its object is to ensure that a person should not be harassed or humiliated
in order to satisfy the grudge or personal vendetta of the complainant. [Reliance
placed on the decision rendered by the Hon’ble Apex Court in HDFC Bank
Limited v. J.J. Mannan and Another (2010 (1) SCC 679); Srikant Upadhyay

5
v. State of Bihar (2024 KHC Online 6137)]. In the case at hand, I find no
exceptional circumstance to exercise the exceptional power of granting
anticipatory bail.

12. Considering the serious allegation against the petitioner and gravity
of the offence, it appears that granting the petitioner with an order of
anticipatory bail will adversely affect the investigation. If an order of
anticipatory bail is granted he is likely to influence the witnesses and tamper
with the evidence. Further, no change in circumstances is brought out after the
dismissal of the earlier bail application. Considering all these aspects, this court
is not inclined to grant an order of pre-arrest bail to the petitioner.

In the result, this petition is dismissed.
Dictated to the Confidential Assistant, transcribed and typed by him, corrected and
pronounced by me in Open Court on this the 3 day of March, 2025
Sd/-
NAZEERA 8S.
SESSIONS JUDGE
